title: Will the Export-Import Bank of the United States be re-authorized before 1 January 2016?
preds: The highway bill reviving the Ex-Im was passed December 3.  (http://www.cnbc.com/2015/12/03/obama-to-sign-new-highway-bill-that-revives-exim-bank-on-friday.html).  Obama signed the bill on December 4.  (http://thehill.com/policy/finance/262171-obama-signs-305b-highway-bill).  Therefore, this question has been satisfied.
following others.  looks like it is all but certain.
This question should be closed retroactive to yesterday if this were a serious forecasting endeavour.

Raising from 95% to 100%.  Overwhelming vote in senate this evening, and White House has said Obama is eager to sign, which is the last step.  http://www.politico.com/story/2015/12/senate-transportation-package-ex-im-renewal-216420

Yes, affirming.  From the sources I quoted earlier, it was make or break for the finance bill this week.  Now that it has passed the House, the Senate also looks good.  I did not see any add-ons that would cause Obama to veto.  So I think we will see this done by end of year.  .

Echoing others.  Pretty much a done deal.
it is included in the highway bill, so looks highly likely

Sounds like the process is moving forward, but slowly. Still a decent chance that it gets derailed and pushed into next year.

My understanding is that the Ex-Im bank re-authorization is tied to the highway funding bill.  Per this source and others, the funding deadline relevant here is this Friday.  This source also indicates that negotiations are underway.  So where I am going with this is, we should see some progress on this issue by this friday or a bit later.  If not, I am going to probably reduce probability, as I am way out on a ledge on this one.  Counting on Congress to do anything is a recipe for indigestion!  
http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/scheduling/261322-this-week
The new wrinkle regarding inserting new language will not affect the passage. Obama may not like it but will not veto it just for that.  This is a slam dunk for passage.

Will the Israeli-Palestinian issue now inserted into the politics of reauthorization, and a likely presidential veto, obstructionism continues to outweigh the national interests with respect to trade.

Reauthorization of the Ex-Im Bank was part of the Highway Bill written by the US Senate.  In the final House votes for the Highway Bill, further amendments to the bill were blocked by a combination of House Republicans and Democrats.  (This is important because amendments coming from the House could have removed the Ex-Im Bank or significantly changed it.  There was enough House support this past June 30 to block reauthorization.)  Funding for this Bill will be part of a joint House-Senate committee before it is passed to the President, but it looks like a done deal at this point.
The votes are there, its all but over.
it's a government program that many corporates say supports US jobs.  GE has made a big case for it.  entering an election yearso may be a push for it.  Not sure of timing but think it will get done.

WSJ, November 5: 'House Passes Highway Bill With Export-Import Bank Renewal': http://www.wsj.com/articles/house-passes-highway-bill-with-export-import-bank-renewal-1446740235
Clip from article:
'The Export-Import Bank, whose charter expired at the end of June after conservatives succeeded in blocking its reauthorization, emerged as a winner in the bill. The bank helps overseas customers of U.S. companies finance purchases with loans and credit guarantees. Supporters of the bank say it keeps U.S. firms on a level playing field against foreign competitors that enjoy similar support from their governments; opponents say it puts taxpayers at risk and allows the government to pick winners and losers.'
Recent predictors' confidence is infectious (somewhat). Raising from 75.

While being a less than reputable organization, the Ex-Im is a "good" source of funding for over-seas company trying to purchase American products. The transportation bill that includes the Ex-Im bank just sailed through the house and senate and the President has stated that he is in favor of the legislation.  Moreover, with the passing of the TPP theoretically more trade should take place between the US and the Asian countries, this means that loans may be more in demand. This should mean the next step would be to reauthorize Ex-Im bank to maximize the the US's gains in the TPP.

The banks see this fy2014 $24b in revs and $675m in profits as that that should be theirs.  They'll definitely raise prices and turn that $24b into $2-3 b in profits for themselves.  This is because they see the govt as telling them what they can and cannot do and the banks can finally tell the govt what to do.  Oh, and they paid congress a lot of money for this new avenue of revenue.

With Paul Ryan as Speaker of the House and with the developments that are going to take place in the world of Far East international trade, the Export-Import Bank should be re-authorized by 1/1/16. I believe this could be Speaker Paul Ryan's first true legislative push in his new position. It will require him to overcome opposition from his fractious party, but I believe that it has a reasonable chance of passing before the end of the year.

The only people opposing it at this point are the "freedom caucus" which is rapidly being frozen out of the decision-making process, and one or two people at the extreme end of the Democratic caucus.  The only question is whether Speaker Ryan will toss the freedom caucus overboard or give in to their demands.  Since the primary beneficiaries are the business community, he'll probably risk offending the the Teahadi's.

I believe this will be a major undertaking of the new Speaker, and the only question is if he can rally the troops. I also believe that he was promised a grace period and if he puts this on the agenda, it will pass.

I believe this will be a major undertaking of the new Speaker, and the only question is if he can rally the troops. I also believe that he was promised a grace period and if he puts this on the agenda, it will pass.

The political environment is stressing jobs over the budget. The recent debates  overlook the costs of operating the government. The Ex-Im bank will pass with some objection, although there are sound private sector alternatives.

The supporters are trying a discharge petition, which would force a floor vote despite commitee-level inaction or disapproval. http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/25/usa-boehner-eximbank-idUSL1N11V27S20150925
"This does bring a sense of urgency to getting this done over the next month with the speaker leaving," said Representative Stephen Fincher, who has led House Republican efforts to renew the export credit agency's charter, which expired nearly three months ago.
Fincher, who on Friday lined up language in his proposed Ex-Im renewal and reform bill with a Senate measure to speed passage, said Congress should vote on the bank's future before a new speaker is installed.
...
Ex-Im supporters say there is support to pass a renewal bill once it can get to the floor, with more than 300 House votes and 67 Senate votes.
However, they don't expect a newly freed Boehner to simply put an Ex-Im bill to a vote, nor attach it to a government funding bill aimed at averting federal agency shutdowns next week.
Fincher said a more likely candidate would be a transportation bill needed by the end of October, adding: "We will use whatever tool we have in the toolbox."

Full Senate is overwhelming in favor of re-authorization. Objections in Senate is on how to bring it forward since there is a notable Republican objection. House Republicans, also,  have a significant contingent against re-authorization. However, with the impending budget year showdown and the associated theatrics, the re-authorization will be attached to the FY16 spending bill and will have support of both Republicans and Democrats.
Would Republicans choose between being charged with harming the economy (in the next general election cycle) or voting for the Boeing bank?

http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/253818-dems-suggest-tying-ex-im-bank-to-spending-bill
"Senate Democrats suggested Wednesday that reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank could be tied to a government funding bill. 

"If we don't get this done and reauthorize the Ex-Im Bank, they're going to eat our lunch," Sen. Amy Klobuchar said. "That's why my colleagues would like to reauthorize the Ex-Im Bank in the bills that we must pass to keep the government operating."
...
The Senate included a reauthorization of the bank in its long-term highway bill, but that legislation is currently tied up in conference committee with House lawmakers.
...
While attaching the bank to a spending bill could complicate efforts to avoid a government shutdown, House Democrats say that bank has more than 275 votes in support."
guessing R-support for Ex-Im is going to be traded for some concession from D.....but not Planned Parenthood.

Not unless the Republican majority have a change of heart. They don't have that many more days before the Thanksgiving and then Christmas recesses. Maybe after January, but even then expect the hardcore opponents in the House will still have the Leader hog tied.

Increasing forecast. Although the timing of re-authorization is not certain, the potential for a steady drum beat of news stories (GM, Boeing already) covering job loses due to lack of EXIM Bank support, will make difference in public opinion, and put pressure on politicians.

The GE move and the Boeing announcement are interesting and colourful, but may not be enough to get some of the R members to walk without using their knuckles.  Nonetheless, there are probably enough votes to push this through pretty quickly once everybody gets back to what they call work.

http://thehill.com/homenews/house/253744-house-conservatives-warm-to-mccarthy-as-speaker
"With Speaker John Boehner’s (R-Ohio) job in doubt, House conservatives have been holding internal talks about a new leadership coalition that could include Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) as Speaker and more conservative members occupying lower rungs on the leadership ladder.
...
GOP leaders face an Oct. 1 deadline to approve a bill to keep the government open. Because a funding bill that blocked money for Planned Parenthood could not pass the Senate, they have no clear path forward for doing so without working with Democrats — something that could spur a conservative move against Boehner.
...
Some Republicans see the idea of a leadership coalition as pure fantasy. But the Freedom Caucus does have enormous leverage: Between 40 to 50 members strong, the conservative bloc of House members essentially could veto any nominee for Speaker simply by withholding all of their votes.

G.E. announced that it would move about 400 jobs to France, whose own export credit agency offered financing for gas turbines, and relocate 100 jobs to Hungary and China to get credit for customers of its advanced aircraft gas turbines. Seems very much a political football.  Has been raised by Obama as required to pass (seemingly reversal of historic boeing bank comments), been attached to Highways Bill, with intent that this gamble will force it to be passed - and senate leaders reprimand Cruz on a Sunday and pass vote for progress.  Not that anyone is really rushing around with stats to keep the bank, but Negatives in GOP seem to be Tea Party orientated, and with Boehner already seeming to indicate the inaction will cause him to pass vote on what senate passes, then I am basing my view that enough political establishment weight will force this through despite the noise; and the noise will be used to raise personal profiles in upcoming election issues.  Negatives in Dems are not weighing on my thinking as they will be whipped into party (Obama) line.  Established Reps see that corporations like Ex-Im and Reps like to be liked by corporations.

I think this is a long siege situation.  Its difficult to find specific numbers on support in the house or senate, but many sources state a majority of both houses would probably vote for this if presented.  But although supporters keep trying to attach it to something or another, the opponents are killing this as a matter of principle.   Its hard for me to see Boehner getting in a fight with the tea party on this issue, and its turned into a presidential election football.

Not much time left for Congress to wrap up lots of "must-dos." I'm guessing this and other minor issues will be approved and rationalized as "the best we can accomplish" in spite of the sturm und drang.

Over 81 years and this is the first time the Ex-IMM bank's charter was allowed to expire?  Given the global economic connectivity and election xenophobic rhetoric, I am not hopeful that it will be reauthorized by 1 January 2016.  It is always easier to renew when it hasn't yet expired; unfortunately not the case this time.  Should it be renewed?  Yes.  Within the timeframe?  Possibly but with the presidential nomination posturing, I think more likely will be around February when manufacturing adds its pressure to agriculture.

Congressional inaction on the Export-Import Bank (preventing reauthorization) will depend on the Boehner agenda and whether the vote will come in the form as a standalone or incorporated into other legislative authorizations.  Given the current impasse among the two major parties, there appears to be little desire to govern; obstruction appears to be the dominant strategy of the 'crazies' in the Congress.
Too many big players with big weight to add to this issue for it to be neglected.

ExIm would pass in the Senate either as a stand-alone bill or attached to the highway bill. Whether it even comes to a vote in the House is uncertain. That would upset Tea Party conservatives and Boehner has spent his entire Speakership trying to avoid that. Maybe it will eventually pass but I see Congress kicking the can down the road on this issue.

I can find little hard data one way or another on this question.  It is not clear to me whether or not the Ex-Im Bank has sufficient support in Congress for re-authorization, and I can't find a clear timeline for a vote.  My position in this sort of case is to go with my default base rate, 25% (based on the percentage of events that happened in the GJP).  I'm averaging this with this with the median forecast of 60% to get my final estimate.

I couldn't find any evidence that there was any panic within the trenches. Yes, it may be a tough fight in the House, but I suspect lobbying by impacted businesses and industry well garner enough support.

I think it's likely to be reauthorized, but it may take awhile. It has support from some large corporations, must Democrats and a number of pro-business republicans. It gets support from a wide range of places. Lobbyists from GE and Boeing are working hard for reauthorization. Opposition is bi-partisan as well, from Bernie Sanders and from the Tea Party. But the bank has been in place since FDR, and it is likely to survive. Likely it will be re-authorized before the end of the year, though that is by no means certain.
It could happen, but I don't think is very likely...
